thread.section_title: Man-eating shark found on road following Cyclone Debbie – Metro
thread.title: Man-eating shark found on road following Cyclone Debbie
thread.title_full: Man-eating shark found on road following Cyclone Debbie

author: georgiadiebelius1
title: Man-eating shark found on road following Cyclone Debbie
text:
The bull shark washed up in a puddle following flooding in Ayr (Picture: EPA/ Queensland Fire and Emergency) When a cyclone hits, people expect to see all kinds of things in the street.
Whether that be trees across the road, cars forced onto their side or even parts of homes that have been tragically destroyed.
Surgeons attach toddler's hand to belly after horse bites his finger off However there’s one thing that people probably don’t think they’ll come across when walking down the road.
And that’s a large man-eating bull shark – one of the most dangerous sharks in the world.
But that’s exactly what happened to locals in Ayr, Australia, following Cyclone Debbie.
And it looks exactly like a scene from 2013 film, Sharknado…
Cyclone Debbie hit Queensland’s north coast this week (Picture: EPA/Queensland Fire and Emergency) Emergency services were left stunned after they discovered the dead shark in a puddle earlier today.
Photos uploaded on social media were shared hundreds of times.
Air stewardess helps to land plane after co-pilot passes out Queensland Fire and Emergency Services used the image to warn people to stay out of murky floodwaters – as sharks or other dangers could be lurking beneath.
They said: ‘Think it’s safe to go back in the water? Think again!
‘You never know what lurks beneath the surface during a severe storm and what will wash up in the aftermath.
‘Just ask emergency services who came across this bull shark during inspections around Ayr, where floodwaters are receding in some parts.’
More: World Circus trainer attacked by lions in terrifying video 
Presenter sacked after calling male student 'gay' for supporting women's rights 
Couple caught having sex on bus in broad daylight 
In January, a man was killed by a crocodile while trying to cross a flooded river in northern Australia.
Police said the 47-year-old was wading through the East Alligator River in the Northern Territory with two women when he disappeared near the World Heritage-listed Kakadu National Park.
His body was discovered downstream near an 11ft crocodile.
